fields.description:
When you change the repository on perforce it tries to clear the directory defined in the client root, however this is changed to the new repository so wont match the old directory structure that actually needs clearing. 

Probably need to look into the logic behind the clearing....
fields.summary: On repository change clearing build directory fails

fields.description: When adding a custom requirement to a build plan, the name does not get stored.  See screenshots.  This happens both when setting up a new build or editing an existing build.

fields.description:
I had a call from a user that spent two hours trying to look for the WAR edition of Bamboo.

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+EAR-WAR+Installation+Guide

In the guide above, the link to the download of the WAR edition of Bamboo shows the Standalone edition unless they click "Show All."  It might be a good idea to mention this in the documentation.
fields.summary: Improve link to download WAR edition of Bamboo

fields.description: I've noticed this a couple of times on JBAC2 now.  If a is currently failing and it passes (i.e. status change), then this change wont be relflected correctly on the dashboard. It happens when you switch from the "Current Activity" tab to the "All Plans" tab after the build status has changed.  Once you do a full refresh (F5), the status is shown correctly.
fields.summary: Build status doesn't update correctly on dashboard until a refresh is done

fields.description:
When viewing the requirements for a plan, it's pretty hard to find the dropdown which displays the agents that can run the build.  Perhaps the text "This plan can only be built by agents whose capabilities meet the 3 requirements below. 4 agents are capable of building the plan." should have some highlighting (or a little info icon maybe) to let the user know that there's more info there when you hover the mouse over it.  I would also find it useful to find out which agents *can't* build this current plan.

The same applies for the admin section where you can configure the agent.  It would be good to be able to see the builds an agent *can't* build, so that I can click through to those builds requirements and figure out why they're not being built.  Maybe add a little toggle "Show builds agent can't build", which is hidden by default and if clicked pops up the list of builds an agent can't build.
fields.summary: Improve the feedback about which agents can build a plan, and what builds an agent can build

fields.description:
The following details should be available for each failed test in a build:
- Test class name
- Test method name
- Result
- Duration
- Exception stack trace

Tracked in IDE Plugin as [PL-116|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/PL-116].
fields.summary: Extend Bamboo REST API to provide access to details of test cases

fields.description:
Customers who are interested in adding support for new testing frameworks would benefit from a general technical implementation guide and/or a short tutorial. A use case of this guide is to add results from an automated browser testing tool such as [Watir|http://wtr.rubyforge.org/] for HTML or [FunFX|http://funfx.rubyforge.org/] for Adobe Flex. It should also mention the requirement for results to be JUnit-style XML format.

It may also be good to emphasise the hosting options we provide to encourage developers to open source their plugins either in this guide or elsewhere in the development hub. This request can be split out if needed.
fields.summary: Document adding support for a new testing framework

fields.description:
Bamboo REST API responses currently consist of a stack trace.  The plug-in needs to be provided with an error description suitable for presentation to end users.

Tracked in the plug-in project as [PL-108|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/PL-108].
fields.summary: Improve Bamboo REST API error response to provide information that can be presented to an end user

fields.description:
In the Capablility_set table, we use a reserved word (KEY) to name a column - this doesn't go well with MYSQL so needs to be fixed!

As a result, the table creation fails - 
{code}
2008-02-18 14:45:24,455 ERROR [btpool0-1] [SchemaExport] You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL server version for the right syntax to use near 'varchar(255), VALUE text, CAPABILITY_SET bigint, primary key (CAPABILITY_ID))' at line 1
2008-02-18 14:45:24,499 ERROR [btpool0-1] [SchemaExport] Unsuccessful: create table REQUIREMENT (REQUIREMENT_ID bigint not null, KEY varchar(255), REGEX_MATCH bit, READONLY_REQ bit, MATCH_VALUE text, REQUIREMENT_SET bigint, primary key (REQUIREMENT_ID))
2008-02-18 14:45:24,500 ERROR [btpool0-1] [SchemaExport] You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL server version for the right syntax to use near 'varchar(255), REGEX_MATCH bit, READONLY_REQ bit, MATCH_VALUE text, REQUIREMENT_S' at line 1
2008-02-18 14:45:24,564 ERROR [btpool0-1] [SchemaExport] Unsuccessful: alter table CAPABILITY add constraint FKEE341118A542349B foreign key (CAPABILITY_SET) references CAPABILITY_SET (CAPABILITY_SET_ID)
2008-02-18 14:45:24,564 ERROR [btpool0-1] [SchemaExport] Table 'mysql.CAPABILITY' doesn't exist
{code}
fields.summary: Mysql integratio with Bamboo 2.0 Beta release 1 doesn't work

fields.description:
There are a significant number of help documents that are hard coded into Bamboo and accessible via the context-sensitive help links. These should be moved into the Bamboo CAC documentation.

=> TO DO: Assess how many help docs are in Bamboo and which should be moved into CAC
=> TO DO: Work with developers to review docs and create appropriate documentation in CAC
fields.summary: Move context-sensitive help documentation into CAC documentation

fields.description:
Add rest (i.e. remote) API info in the bamboo docs - likely in the developer hub.
Currently it is hardcoded into Bamboo.
fields.summary: Add rest API info in the bamboo docs

fields.description:
Variable substitution doesn't seem to work in Bamboo 2.0 beta.

For e.g, passing down svn=${bamboo.custom.svn.revision.number} to a bash script in Bamboo 2.0 beta, doesn't pass down the SVN revision number.

Reported in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-578
fields.summary: Variable substitution doesn't work in Bamboo 2.0.

fields.description:
My Bamboo server is up and running on the Ubuntu box and churning away with no problems (that I can tell at least). I'm trying to run the remote agent on a Windows XP box and I'm getting the following exception. Command line included so you can see if I've done something silly!

C:\bamboo-agent>java -jar -Dbamboo.agent.ignoreServerCertName=true -Dbamboo-home=c:/bamboo-agent-home bamboo-agent-2.0-beta1.jar http://148.92.244.109:8085/agentServer
Remote agent could not start. Retrying in 30 seconds.
java.io.IOException: HTTP status code 404 received in response to fingerprint request.
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.bootstrap.AgentContext.httpException(AgentContext.java:21)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.bootstrap.AgentContext.<init>(AgentContext.java:72)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.bootstrap.AgentBootstrap.run(AgentBootstrap.java:74)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.bootstrap.AgentBootstrap.main(AgentBootstrap.java:25)
fields.summary: Agent bootstrap doesn't handle paths without trailing /

fields.description:
After each build, as I understand, bamboo adds the build results to it's internal lucene index located at /usr/atlassian/bamboo/data/index.
After a few weeks of running on our plattform, this directory includes several hundreds possibly thousands of files. A simple "ls" does not return data unless you're willing to wait for it for some minutes.
The more severe problem however is, that bamboo itself is - from one moment to the next - suddenly extremely slow, when adding results to the index. It feels as if it crossed some boundary after which adding additional entries to the index gets incredibly slow.

Once this happens - typically during daytime - there's not really the time to start an "optimize index". Therefore I'd suggest to do an "auto optimize" of that index once it either reaches a certain size (number of documents) or if it wasn't done for some time, thus having a "auto optimize scheduler".
fields.summary: Auto-Optimize Index in scheduled manner

fields.description:
It'd handy to be able to pass down metadata about the parent build that triggerred off the current build. This will allow the information to be passed into the build process (e.g. Maven) to use this information to chain their builds. 

So you might have:

{noformat}
dependency.parent.0 = JRA-MAIN-102
dependency.parent.1 = JRA-UNIT14-56
dependency.parent.2 = JRA-FUNC14-12
{noformat}

where JRA-MAIN-102 is the originating build that kicked off this entire tree. We could even add some extra tool to show this graphically

{{bamboo.dependency.parent.0}} would be available to the underlying build process where it could be used to retrieve artifacts or extra information about the originating build.
fields.summary: Dependencies should pass down meta data about the dependency chain

fields.description: If you trigger a plan twice in a row on a system configured with more than one agent, the plan. is done concurrently on the 2 agent. While building concurrently 2 distinct plans is a very nice and welcome feature, building the same plans concurrently seems weird. For exemple if the plan does some deployment, you may have a lot of concurrency problem. The comportment would be less error-prone if their was one build-queue per plan.
fields.summary: The same plan can be run concurrently on two agents

fields.description:
Currently, users can't specify the client resource while connecting to IM server.

Bamboo by default, is hard coded to use Bamboo as the connecting resource, we should either -
1) Add a text field to allow users to define the Jabber resource, in the IM server configuration page.
2) Or allow users to pass this in as a  System property to Bamboo.
fields.summary: Add a mechanism to define the Jabber resource in Bamboo.

fields.description:
With postgresql, when I try to define which builder to use, only Script is available, even if others builders are defined.

 Looking at the log I saw:

net.sf.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter logExceptions ATTENTION: SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 42883
net.sf.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter logExceptions GRAVE: ERROR: function locate(character varying, character varying) does not exist

 I added the two following functions to my database (not sure the second is needed)

{noformat}
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION locate("substring" "varchar", string "varchar")
RETURNS int4 AS
'select position(lower($1) in lower($2));'
LANGUAGE 'sql' VOLATILE;
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION locate("substring" "varchar", string "varchar", "position" int4)
RETURNS int4 AS
$BODY$select CASE WHEN locate($1, substring($2, $3)) = 0
THEN 0
ELSE
$3 + locate($1, substring($2, $3)) - 1
END$BODY$
LANGUAGE 'sql' VOLATILE;
{noformat}

 and after that bamboo seems to be working just fine.
fields.summary: Bamboo use a unexistant SQL function with postgreSQL

The automatic installer on Mac finishes with the message "The application may be launched by double-clicking the installed icons".

We should fix this.  It could lead to confusing and disappointing first impressions.

fields.description:
The build monitor is very cool (http://opensource.bamboo.atlassian.com/telemetry.action). But we get only one column and only a few rows on the screen. Can you add a new parameter to set the column count?

Example for tree columns:
| Apache - Directory Server | Apache - Directory Server 1.0 | Apache - Directory Server 1.0 |
| Apache Felix - Default | Apache Felix - Default | Jetty - Main Build |
fields.summary: Build Monitor (telemetry.action) parameter for column count
Add operating system as a "System" capability

fields.description:
On plan deletion, it is necessary to have a way Bamboo do some repository cleaning tasks related to the SCM plugin.
Currently, we are having issues with the Clearcase plugin. When we delete a plan, Bamboo's standard behavior of erasing the source files on Bamboo-home directory is insufficient. Clearcase maintains several internal structures (namely views and streams) that need to be removed. Today, the intervention of a Clearcase administrator is needed, when these tasks could be  programatically accomplished by the plugin.
Maybe other repositories need a similar behavior.
See http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=22427&tstart=0 for some extra info.
fields.summary: On plan deletion, add the ability to do repository maintenance tasks
Disallow directory listing in Jetty.

fields.description:

fields.summary: User context in remote API is not tied to authentication token

fields.description:
TestNG (a successor to JUnit) provides a mechanism that lets you skip execution of tests whenever prior tests upon which they depend fail. Such tests are reported as being "skipped", as opposed to either "passed" or "failed".

We need to implement support for this third category of test results.

Surefire 2.4 provides support for reporting "skipped" tests.
fields.summary: Implement support for TestNG's ability to skip tests

fields.description:
We don't validate user input, in the label field for a new builder in the viewBuilders!default.action  - so a user is able to specify special characters for builder label. For e.g *@$%~maven*

This persists fine - but when user goes to edit the builder the following exception is thrown -
{code]
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.configuration.plugins.ConfigureBuilder.doEdit(ConfigureBuilder.java:88)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
        .................................
{code}
Also, the user is unable to delete the builder from Bamboo - the only way to delete the builder, is to hack the adminstration.xml file.

Use database, rather than Lucene, for indexing of highly structured data

fields.description:
See http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAEXT/JIRA+Bamboo+Plugin?focusedCommentId=127795720#comment-127795720

It seems that in certain circumstances, the JIRA Bamboo plugin doesn't rewrite the paths correctly.

We need to try to reproduce this issue. It seems the "best case" test seems to work fine.
fields.summary: URL rewrite issue with JIRA's Bamboo plugin
Make Global System Variables accessible on the post actions page.

fields.description:
As above, the SVN implementation in Bamboo expects username to be entered seperately in the username field.

Bamboo will fail validate SVN connection if the Repository URL is of the format svn+ssh://user@host/repo.

Issue reported in [BSP-536|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-536]
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't validate SVN connection if URL is of the format svn+ssh://user@host/repo

fields.description:
When Bamboo can't find tests or the test output is not parsable - Bamboo fails builds with "No failed tests found, a possible compilation error."

I think the message should be little more specific and unambiguous. E.g: 

Sorry, Bamboo could not find your tests please recheck the location of tests specified.
OR
Bamboo can't parse the XML file, please ensure it conforms to standard JUnit XML ouput.

Issue raised due to https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-537
fields.summary: Rename "No failed tests found, a possible compilation error." error to something meaningful.
Plugins may not respect the skipIfFailed tag

fields.description:
Hi Adrian,

Just raising this ticket to make sure I don't forget about this piece of documentation. Please feel free to come grab me when you have time to work on this.

Cheers,
Andrew
fields.summary: Document customer advice regarding security considerations for Bamboo Beta

fields.description: Just a reminder to create a knowledge base article to document  use of SSH private keys, SSL certificates.
fields.summary: Better document  the  use of SSH private keys/SSL certificates for SVN authentication in Bamboo.

fields.description:
See attached image.  On the Number of Tests chart for the plan "Producer Manager - Test and Build", the graph indicates that there were no tests on January 26.  This is because there were no commits (it was a Saturday), and therefore no builds.  The graph misleads the viewer into believing that something went wrong with the test suite on that day.

Ideally, Bamboo should not render a data point if there were no builds during a given time slice.
fields.summary: Don't render false data points when there is no data

fields.description: Will require substantial revisions to test cases.
fields.summary: Build is automatically triggered upon definition of a new plan, even for manual builds

fields.description: If you choose a non standard database, select a datasource (eg. JNDI), you won't be able to choose a Hibernate dialect.
fields.summary: You cannot specify a Hibernate dialect when using a datasource and "other" database

fields.description: If the build fails because the code did not meet Clover coverage requirements, this should be recognized by Bamboo and shown in the summary box on the build page and in the notification emails. Currently, the message is "No failed tests found, a possible compilation error." Let's integrate our products more...Bamboo should know (more deeply than it currently knows) when Clover makes the build fail. And that info should be in the notification emails so users don't have to go to the build page to find out.
fields.summary: Better integration with Clover on build failure

fields.description:
After multiple repositories (BAM-1868 BAM-955) / multiple modules per plan (BAM-1015 BAM-1211) is implemented, the builder will have to cope with the situation that more than one directories in the sand box contains the POM - in a frequent scenario one of the directories will be the parent module and the other will be the actual module that needs to be built. It this situation is necessary that the correct POM can be selected during plan creation.
The change would be backward compatible - not entering POM location would result in POM lookup performed in the same way it is done now.
fields.summary: allow location of POM be specified for Maven / Maven2 builders

fields.description: I have a Bamboo plan dedicated to doing maven release:prepare for my project. This is very convenient for automating the process and distributing the release.properties as an artifact. However, it becomes a little confusing that the labels for the builds are always listed as PROJECT-PLAN-BUILDNUMBER. It would be really nice if I could add the maven ${project.parent.version} to the end of that build label, so it would appear as something like MYPROJECT-MYPLAN-21-5.0.85. This would make navigating the history of the plan more meaningful, since the bamboo build numbers don't correlate to the Maven releases.
fields.summary: Integrate Maven version numbers into bamboo build labels

fields.description:
Currently, as I understand, Bamboo queues a build the moment a change is detected within the source repository.  Several times tonight, I have attempted to commit a batch of several changes, and had the build launch right in the middle of my commits, so that yet another build was launched after the first build eventually completed.  (I understand this might not be the subversion way of doing things, but I like to document (multiple) clusters of changes, which cannot be all committed atomically.)

I recommend you offer an additional feature when configuring the polling:  boolean: "Wait until after first subsequent quiet poll before queuing build."  In other words, when this feature is selected, once polling indicates there are changes, wait until after the first poll where there are no (more) changes, before queuing the next build.
fields.summary: wait until after changes are detected before launching build
